turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I tell ya the guy's a phony.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Phony, huh?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: As a three-dollar bill.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Sez who?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Sez me! Amy Archer. Why is he an Idea Man -- because Hudsucker says he is? What're his ideas? Why won't they let anyone interview him?...

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: ...On payday! The only story here is how this guy made a monkey out of you, Al.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Yeah, well, monkey or not I'm still editor of this rag. Amy, I thought you were doing that piece on the F.B.I. -- J. Edgar Hoover: When Will He Marry?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I filed it yesterday.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, do a follow-up: Hoover: Hero or Mama's Boy? The rest of you bums get up off your brains and get me that Idea Man story!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: I can't print this!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Why not, it's all true! The board is using this poor guy! They're depressing the stock so they can buy it cheap!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: It's pure speculation! Why, they'd have my butt in a satchel!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: You don't know anything! Fact is they haven't bought it! The stock is cheap, Archer! What're they waiting for?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Muncie.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Whatever. That's what sells newspapers.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I've got an even hotter story -- The Sap from the City Desk.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Watch it, Archer --

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It's about a dimwitted editor who --

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You can't print that!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: He grins wolfishly.

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Archer, you're a broken record. Fact is Gunderson did design it -- apparently he's some kind of prodigy --

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Says who?!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Whatever! It's no dig on you, Archer, but this story is hot and you're no longer on top of it. Why, it's the scoop of the century -- the other papers won't have the Gunderson dope 'til tomorrow -- The Allemeinischer Zeitung, Le Figaro, they'll be choking on our dust come mornin' --

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You're fools, both of you! It's obvious they're out to crucify Norville! They're trying to destroy him!

turns.speaker: CHIEF
turns.text: Amy -- take a break. You've worked hard on this story -- heck, you broke it for us! But it's passed you by and Smith here has taken up the slack.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Just got hired today!

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Ya know, entry level!

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: I got big ideas, though!

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: I'm sure you do.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: For instance, take a look at this sweet baby...

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: Terrific.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: So ya see, I won't be in the mailroom long.

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: Nooo, I don't guess you will be.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: How long've you been down here?

turns.speaker: ANCIENT SORTER
turns.text: Forty-eight years...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: I want a martini! It's New Year's Eve and I want a Martini!

turns.speaker: BARMAN
turns.text: Daddy, it's like I been tellin' ya --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: I thought you served misfits here!

turns.speaker: BARMAN
turns.text: Yeah, daddy, that's a roger, but we don't sell alcohol.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: What kind of bar is it if ya can't get a martini?!

turns.speaker: BARMAN
turns.text: It's a juice and coffee bar, man, like I been tellin' ya --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: I want a martini! On this bar, right now! I've had a martini in every bar on the way down here, and I'm not about to --

turns.speaker: BARMAN
turns.text: Martinis are for squares, man.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: What the heck's she doin', Lou?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What the heck they doin'?

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: You know what they're doin' now, Lou.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: This I know, Benny.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: This you're familia' with.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: ...Geez.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: ...Geez.

turns.speaker: BENNY
turns.text: ...It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: ...What's your pleasure, buddy?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Forty-fourth floor, and it's very --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Forty-four, the top brass floor say, buddy! What takes fifty years to get up to the top floor and thirty seconds to get down?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Say, buddy!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Say, buddy! Who's the most liquid businessman on the street?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Well, I --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Say, buddy! When is the sidewalk fully dressed? When it's 'wearing' Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: My pleasure, sir.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Roast tom turkey. Gee, I'm hungry too --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh, uh... Buzz... Is it important?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: I like to think so! It's this little idea I been working on!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...Why, this is worthless.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Huh?! But, buddy --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: This is the most idiotic thing I've ever seen in my life!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Yeah, but, buddy --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Nobody wants a hare-brained product like this! Ya see, Buzz, it lacks the creative spark, the unalloyed genius that made, uh...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...say, the hula hoop such a success.

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: But, buddy --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: And what do you mean barging in here and taking up my valuable time! I've got a company to run here --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: But, buddy, you were --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: -- I can't have every deadbeat on the Hudsucker payroll pestering me with their idiotic brainwaves!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Geez, I'm sorry, buddy --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: An example must be made!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Wuddya mean, buddy?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Fired! You're fired! Is that plain enough for you, buster!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Awwww, buddy --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: And don't call me buddy! Out of here! Out!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Aw, please, sir -- this job, it's all I got!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Get up!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: I understand if ya don't like the Buzz-Sucker! Just lemme keep my job, I'm prayin' to ya!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: We don't crawl at Hudsucker Industries! Get out of my office! Leave your uniform in the locker room!

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: I'm sorry, buddy... I'm sorry...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Buzz... off! Ha-ha-ha-ha!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: -- Uh... Buzz, I'm sorry, I -- Buzz, you gotta forgive me! I shouldn't a fired you, I didn't know what I was doing! I was a little funny in the head, I --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Aw, buddy, I don't care about that.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...You don't?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Nah, that's all forgotten.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...It is?

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Sure, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid said I could have the job back.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Absolutely, Buzz, I'm glad he --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: But he told me you stole that swell hoop idea from me. What gives!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But, Buzz --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: Say, that was a swell idea!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But, Buzz, you know I never --

turns.speaker: BUZZ
turns.text: And Sid says you stole it!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But Buzz --

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: ...Jesus Christopher -- That smarts... Where was I? Oh yeah, the board. I guess Sidney's been puttin' the screws to ya, huh, Norman?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Norville.

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Mm. Well, say what you like about the man's ethics, he's a balls-to- the-wall businessman. Beat ya any way he can. Straight for the jugular. Very effective.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Yes sir...

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Anyway. Any particular reason you didn't give him my Blue Letter? I mean, Jesus, Norman, just a dying man's last words and wishes, no big deal.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Huh? Oh, geez, Mr. Hudsucker, I apologize, there was an awful lot of excitement and I guess I must've mislaid --

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: It's sittin' in your apron pocket, right where you left it. Imbecile.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh, geez.

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Failure to deliver a Blue Letter is grounds for dismissal.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Geez, I --

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Ah, it's New Year's, I'm not gonna add to your woes. I'm just saying.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Yessir.

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Well, why don't ya read it.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Yeah, go ahead. Might learn somethin'.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Yes sir...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: 'From the desk of Waring Hudsucker. To. Sidney J. Mussburger. Regarding. My demise. Dear Sid. By the time you read this, I will have joined the organization upstairs -- an exciting new beginning. I will retain fond memories of the many years you and I -- '

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, it's the standard resignation boilerplate -- go down to the second paragraph.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: 'Many years, uh... I know that you will be wondering why I have decided to move on, ending my tenure at Hudsucker, and here on Earth. You will be thinking, Why now, when things are going so well? Granted, from the standpoint of our balance sheet and financials, sure, sure, we're doing fine. However, Sid. These things have long since ceased to give me pleasure. I look at myself now and no longer see the idealistic young man who started this company. Now I see only an empty shell whom others call a 'success.' How has this come to pass? When and why did I trade all of my hopes, dreams and aspirations, for the emptiness of power and wealth? What the heck have I done?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: '...And so, Sid, the future does not belong to such as I -- nor even you. We have made our compromises with time. The future belongs to the young, who may more energetically wage the battle against corruption. Accordingly, in the spirit of hope, and the ringing in of the new, I hereby bequeath my entire interest in the company, and my seat on the board, to whomever is Hudsucker's most recent employee at the time of my demise. I know this will disappoint you -- you, Sid, who have served so diligently and for so long. But --'

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: -- tough titty toenails!

turns.speaker: HUDSUCKER
turns.text: ...Yeah, go ahead.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: '...But Sid, let me urge you to work closely with the new president, and to keep giving Hudsucker Industries all your energies -- but not your soul. For while we must strive for success, we must not worship it. Long live the Hud. Waring Hudsucker...'

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...This'll only take a moment.

turns.speaker: INTERCOM
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Good afternoon to ya, this is Norville Barnes --

turns.speaker: INTERCOM
turns.text: Barnes! Where the hell have you been! And where's my voucher?!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...Well, I'm not sure where I --

turns.speaker: INTERCOM
turns.text: I need that voucher! I told you a week ago it was important!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But look, I'm president of the company now and I --

turns.speaker: INTERCOM
turns.text: I don't care if you're president of the company! I need that voucher! Now!

turns.speaker: MRS. MUSSBURGER
turns.text: -- So we'd gone out to the Hamptons and the garden was in positive ruins!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: That must have been quite a disappointment, Mrs. Mussburger.

turns.speaker: MRS. MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Disappointment? J'etais destroyee! I was in bed for a week! Positively sick with fury! I called in the gardener and said, 'Monsieur Gonzalez, either those azaleas come up next spring or you are terminee!

turns.speaker: MRS. MUSSBURGER
turns.text: I'm brushing up on my French with the most charming man, Pierre of Fifth Avenue. Do you know him?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: I haven't had --

turns.speaker: MRS. MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Sidney and I are planning a trip to Paris and points continental -- Aren't we, dear?

turns.speaker: MRS. MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Well, frankly, I...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: You have a charming wife, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: ...Who let you in?

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Tell him I'll be right there...  Well, what is it?

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: You, maybe you're the company's biggest moron. We can't use Morris, he's been with us too long, he's a nice guy, too many friends. Matter of fact, why don't you fire him. No -- scratch that; I'll fire him.  ...Make it fast, make it fast.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: You --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...You know, for kids! Which is perfect for Hudsucker -- not that I claim to be any great genius; like they say, inspiration is 99 percent perspiration, and in my case I'd say it's at least twice that, but I gotta tell ya, Mr. Mussburger, sir, this sweet baby --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Wait a minute!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: ...education, were you?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Well, I'm a college graduate --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: All right, but you didn't excel in your studies...?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Well, I made the dean's list.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Hmmm.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: At the Muncie College of Business Administration.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Sure, sure. And did your classmates there call you 'jerk' or...  ...'schmoe'?

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: ...'Shnook'? 'Dope'? 'Dipstick'? 'Lamebrain'?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Not even behind your back?

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Sir! They voted me most likely to succeed!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: You're fired.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But, sir! --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Get your feet off that desk.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Get out of my sight.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: My God! The Bumstead contracts!!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh my God, sir!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: You nitwit! I worked for three years on this deal!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh my God, sir!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Why you nitwit. You almost destroyed the most sensitive deal of my career!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh my God, sir!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Not that way! Through the door!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: But, sir!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Up on your feet! We don't crawl at Hudsucker Industries!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Sir, my leg is on fire!

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: My God! The Bumstead contracts!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Oh my God, sir!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: That reminds me, Mr. Mu... uh, Sid. I never did give you that--

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Lobby. We haven't got all day.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Relax, Norville. It's only natural in a period of transition for the more nervous element to run for cover.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Okay, Sid. Like I said, you're the expert, but --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: ...You don't happen to remember the plan I outlined to you the day I set fire to your off -- uh, the day I was promoted?

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: I do remember and I was impressed. Anyway, that's all forgotten now. Driver!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Thank you, Sid, but the reason I mention it is, it would require such a small capital investment -- again, you're the expert here --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Damnit, where's my car!

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: -- But there's such an enormous potential profit-wise given the demographics -- baby boom -- discretionary income in the burgeoning middle class --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Finally.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: -- So if you think it's appropriate, I'd like to bounce the idea off a few people at lunch --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: ...Congratulations, kid, you've really outdone yourself. Reinvented the wheel. I'm going to recommend to the Board that we proceed immediately with this, uh... with the, uh... that the dingus be mass-produced with all deliberate speed. Of course, as president of the company the ultimate decision is yours.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Well... I'm for it...

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Sorry I'm late, Sid. That back nine at Riverdale is really murder.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Sure, sure, it's a tough course. Well thanks for coming, kid. I thought the board room would be a swell place to chat undisturbed -- it seems we're having some security problems here at the Hud.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Ya don't say.

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Mm. Ordinarily I wouldn't bother you with it, but -- this is embarrassing, kid -- it seems to concern you directly.

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: How's that, Sid?

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: It's not important in itself -- some elevator boy you fired came to me claiming you'd stolen the idea for the, uh, the hoop dingus from him --

turns.speaker: NORVILLE
turns.text: Huh?! He -- no, I -- he's just -- maybe I was a little rough on the boy, ya see I --

turns.speaker: MUSSBURGER
turns.text: Ah forget it, kid, ya don't have to explain to me. He's a little person. He's nothing. Like I say, ordinarily it would just be a nuisance. But it seems -- well, there was a spy in the company...

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: I got gas, Bennie.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Yeah, tell me about it.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: No kiddin', Bennie. I got gas.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Ya get the special?

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: Fah from it...

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: ...Enter the dame.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: There's one in every story.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: Ten bucks says she's looking for a handout.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Twenty bucks says not here she don't find one.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: She's looking for her mark.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: She finds him.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: She sits down.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: ...and awduhs a light lunch.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: She looks in her purse...

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: ...No money.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: The mark notices.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: ...He's not noticing, Benny.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: Maybe he's wise.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: He don't look wise.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: Plan two: Here come the waterworks.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Yellowstone.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: Old Faithful.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Hello, Niagara.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: He notices.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: She's got other problems, of course...

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: ...Her mother needs an operation...

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: ...adenoids.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: No, Bennie: Lumbago.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: Maybe he's wise.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: He don't look wise.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: She isn't!

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: She is!

turns.speaker: VETERAN #1
turns.text: She's good, Bennie.

turns.speaker: VETERAN #2
turns.text: She's damn good, Lou.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Good morning, miss.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you for waking me.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: I didn't want to frighten you out of your sleep, Miss.  That's why I touched you farthest from your heart.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But I'm Miss Jessica's nurse, Alma. You don't have to do that for me.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: I know, miss.  But I like to do it. I like to tend for Miss Jessica and I want to tend for you.  You settle right back, now, and I'll mix you your coffee.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you, Alma.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Miss Jessica used to say this is the only way for a lady to break her fast -- in bed, with a lacy cushion to bank her head up. If you'd only seen her, Miss Connell. She looked so pretty.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: She must have been beautiful.  What happened to her, Alma?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: She was very sick and then she went mindless, Miss.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: We'll see if we can't make her well, Alma, you and I.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: I do my best.  Every day I dress her just as beautifully as if she was well.  It's just like dressing a great, big doll.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: A puff-up, I call it.  But Miss Jessica always says "brioche."

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Looks like an awful lot of breakfast -- I don't know whether I'll be able to get away with it.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Things so bad, nobody can help -- not even Doctor Maxwell.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Doctors and nurses can only do so much, Alma.  They can't cure everything.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Doctors that are people can't cure everything.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: What do you mean -- "doctors that are people"?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: There are other doctors...Yes, other doctors...Better doctors...

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: At the Houmfort.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's nonsense, Alma.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: They even cure nonsense, Miss Betsy.  Mama Rose was mindless.  I was at the Houmfort when the Houngan brought her mind back.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You mean Mama Rose was like Mrs. Holland?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: No.  She was mindless but not like Miss Jessica.  But the Houngan cured her.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Are you trying to tell me that the Houngan -- the voodoo priest -- could cure Mrs. Holland?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Yes, Miss Betsy.  I mean that.  The Houngan will speak to the rada drums and the drums will speak to Shango and Damballa.

turns.speaker: COACHMAN
turns.text: Times gone, Fort Holland was a fort...now, no longer.  The Holland's are a most old family, miss.  They brought the colored people to the island-- the colored folks and Ti-Misery.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Ti-Misery?  What's that?

turns.speaker: COACHMAN
turns.text: A man, miss -- an old man who lives in the garden at Fort Holland - with arrows stuck in him and a sorrowful, weeping look on his black face.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Alive?

turns.speaker: COACHMAN
turns.text: No, miss.  He's just as he was in the beginning -- on the front part of an enormous boat.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You mean a figurehead.

turns.speaker: COACHMAN
turns.text: If you say, miss.  And the enormous boat brought the long-ago Fathers and the long-ago Mothers of us all - chained down to the deep side floor.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But they came to a beautiful place, didn't they?

turns.speaker: COACHMAN
turns.text: If you say, miss.  If you say.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I think you need some help.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'm afraid so.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Ti-Joseph?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I really intended going out to the Fort and meeting you long before this, Miss Connell.  I'm Mrs. Rand -- Wesley's mother.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Oh, Mrs. Rand --

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Come, come, don't tell me how sorry you are that I should meet you this way.  I'm even a little glad that Wesley's difficulty brought us together.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Believe me, Mrs. Rand, he doesn't do this often. This is the first time I've seen him --

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Nonsense, child!  I know Wesley's been drinking too much lately.  I know a great deal more about what goes on at Fort Holland than you'd think.  I know all about you -- that you're a nice girl, competent and kind to Jessica.  The Fort needs a girl like you.  But now we've got to get you back there.  I'll walk you back and stay over night.  It'll be a nice change for me.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you, Mrs. Rand.  I think you're every bit as nice as Wes says you are.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: So -- he says I'm nice.  He's a nice boy, too, Miss Connell, a very nice boy.  But I'm worried about his drinking.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I'd love to.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Use your influence with Paul.  Ask him to take that whiskey decanter off the dinner table.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I've no influence with Mr. Holland.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Try it -- you may have more influence than you think.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Some of this native nonsense. The Houngan has his prescription and Dr. Maxwell and I have ours.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You've never said anything about voodoo before, Mrs. Rand.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Haven't I?  I suppose I take it for granted. It's just part of everyday life here.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: You don't believe in it?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: A missionary's widow?  It isn't very likely, is it?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't mean believe, like believing in a religion.  I mean, do you believe it has power?  Do you think it could heal a sick person?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Frankly, my dear, I didn't expect anything like this from a nice level-headed girl.  What are you driving at?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I heard the servants talking about someone called Mama Rose. They said she had been "mindless"...

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Her son drowned.  She brooded until her mind was affected. All the Houngan did was coax her out of it with a little practical psychology.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Mrs. Rand.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Wait. Don't draw any conclusions. Let me explain.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But, Mrs. Rand --

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I knew you'd come. And I knew I'd have to come up here and talk to you. I couldn't let you go back without any word. I came to tell you again -- Jessica cannot be cured.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But how did you get here? What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: I asked you to let me explain. It's a long story.  And not an easy one --

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: -- and when my husband died I felt helpless. They disobeyed me -- things went from bad to worse. All my husband's dreams of good health, good sanitation, good morals for these sweet and gentle people seemed to die with him.  Then, almost accidentally, I discovered the secret of how to deal with them. There was a girl with a baby -- again and again I begged her to boil the drinking water. She never would. Then I told her the god, Shango, would be pleased and kill the evil spirits in the water if she boiled it. She boiled the water from then on.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But you didn't have to come up here.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Perhaps not.  But I did come here and I found it was so simple to let the gods speak through me. Once started, it seemed such an easy way to do good.  I should have known there was no easy way to do good, Betsy.

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: Why, Betsy -- we can't lose you. You mean too much to us here.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That's sweet of you, Mrs. Rand.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Mrs. Rand...

turns.speaker: MRS. RAND
turns.text: You must, Betsy. They'll have to believe you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Mrs. Rand was at the Houmfort that night.  But there's nothing wrong with that.  She's gone there for years -- trying to take care of those people,  to help them.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Does she suffer?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I don't know.  I prefer to think of her as a sleepwalker who can never be awakened -- feeling nothing, knowing nothing.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: She can never be cured?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I've never heard of a cure.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Is this disease common in the tropics?

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Fortunately, not.  This is my first experience with it as a physician. But I have seen half-witted field hands -- whom the other peasants call Zombies.  I am sure they suffer from a similar destruction of spinal nerves as the result of high fever.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: I prepared these for you last night, Miss Connell.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I've worked with it.  I've seen cures. It is at least a hope.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: It's the very danger itself that makes the cure possible, Mr. Holland.  The insulin produces a state of coma, a stupor.  The patient is revived from the coma by a violent overwhelming nerve shock. That nerve shock can kill -- but it can also restore the damaged mind.

turns.speaker: DR. MAXWELL
turns.text: Miss Connell's testimony will be very important.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I would have stayed anyway, Dr. Maxwell.

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: You're single?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: Where were you trained?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: At the Memorial Hospital -- here in Ottawa.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: They didn't teach it at Memorial Hospital.  I had my suspicions, though, about the Directress of Training.

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: Very well.  That means that you have met all Mr. Holland's requirements.  Now, as to salary -- it's quite good -- two hundred dollars a month.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That is good.  But I'd like to know more about the case.

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that the patient is a young woman -- the wife of a Mr. Paul Holland with whom we do considerable business.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: That will mean another interview, won't it?

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: No, this is quite final.  You see, Mr. Holland is a sugar planter.  He lives in St. Sebastian Island in the West Indies.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: The West Indies?

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: A year's contract -- a trip with all expenses paid -- that's not so bad, you know.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: But it's so far away...

turns.speaker: WILKENS
turns.text: That's rather nice, isn't it?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: It seems we are having dinner by ourselves, Miss Connell.  But I may as well introduce everyone to you, anyway.  There -- in the master's chair, sits the master -- my half-brother Paul Holland.  But you've already met him.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Yes -- on the boat.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: And that chair --  is the particular property of Mrs. Rand -- mother to both of us and much too good for either of us. Too wise, in fact, to live under the same roof. She prefers the village dispensary.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Is she a doctor?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: No -- she just runs the place. She's everything else -- amazing woman, mother.  You'll like her.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I like her already.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: And that --  is my chair.  And this --  is Miss Connell -- who is beautiful.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Thank you.  But who sits there?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: My brother's wife.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: -- But, you're an American?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I went to school in Buffalo.  Paul went to school in England.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I wondered about your different accents.  I'm still wondering about your names -- Rand and Holland.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: We're half-brothers.  Paul is mother's first child.  When his father died, she married my father. Dr. Rand, the missionary.  And you know what they say about missionaries' children.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: As a matter of fact, it means the sugar syrup is ready to be poured off.  You'll have to excuse me.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Of course.  It's been nice of you to spend this much time with me.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Don't worry.  I wasn't missed.  The only important man here is the owner.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Mr. Holland?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Yes, the redoubtable Paul.  He has the plantation, and I, as you must have noticed, have all the charm.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I don't know.  He spoke to me last night on the boat. I liked him very much.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Ah, yes, our Paul, strong and silent and very sad -- quite the Byronic character. Perhaps I ought to cultivate it.

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: Perhaps you ought to get on to the mill.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: It'll wait.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: It's my day off.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: But what in the world can you do with a day off in St. Sebastian?

turns.speaker: BETSY
turns.text: I was just beginning to wonder. Aren't there shops, restaurants and things?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Well -- and things -- might be a better description of what you'll find.  I'd better come along and show you the town.
